DeregistrationReasonOtherText: facility was converted from extraction plant to compressor station.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Excess Flow Valves and Snappy Joe Valves
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Accidental Release Prevention Program



The Oneida Extraction Plant is subject to OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management for Highly Hazardous Chemicals(PSM).  The PSM program was implemented in January of 2002.



The Oneida Extraction Plant is also subject to EPA's 40 CFR 112.7 Spill Prevention Countermeasures and Control standard.  An SPCC is in place to establish procedures to prevent contain and control a hydrocarbon release.



The Oneida Extraction Plant complies with NFPA standard 58.



In the unlikely event of a fire at the Oneida Extraction Plant, employees may respond to an incipient stage fire and then must evacuate the facility.  An Emergency Action Plan developed to 29 CFR 1910.38(a) is in place to establish procedures for the safe evacuation of the facility and summon emergency response organizations. The Oneida Extraction Plant has coordinated response with the Oneida Volunteer Fire Department.  Members of the fire department have inspected the Liquid Storage System.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Description and Regulated Substances Handled



The Oneida Extraction Plant facility, located in Clay County Kentucky , is a Natural Gas Dewpoint Control plant designed to process 14 MMscf of Natural Gas per day. The compression was brought on-line in January 16, 2001.  The process was brought on line May 2001. The facility is manned 10 hours daily. 



Low pressure inlet gas (currently approximately 9.5 MMscfd) enters the facility from two CHK gathering systems.  The high side, Leslie County #1 & #2, is delivered to the plant via an 8" pipeline at approximately 75 psig. The low side, Clay County #1 & #2, is delivered to the plant via an 8" pipeline at approximately 7 psig.  The gas is compressed by two identical Natural Gas Engine drive reciprocating gas compressors to process pressure of approximately 350 psig.  The gas is dehydrated using Tri-ethylene Glycol (TEG) prior to entering the propane refrigeration stripper portion of the process.  



Overhead vapors (residue gas) from the stripper portion of the process with a volume of 8.5 MMscfd is delivered through two (2) outlets to the Columbia Gas Transmission Pipeline (KA1) and the Somerset Manchester 8.  Liquids leaving the stripper portion of the process flow to the storage area of the facility. 

    

The facility produces approximately 6000 gallons a day of Butanes plus (Propane/Butane mix) product stream with a composition of 2 % Ethane, 35.2 % Propane, 9% iso-Butane, 27.7% n-Butane, 7% iso-pentane and 9% n-Pentane.  The balance of the fluid mix is heavy ends commonly known as C6 plus (Hexane, Heptane, Octane and Nonane). Ethane, Propane, iso-Butane, n-Butane iso-Pentane and n-Pentane are regulated substances each with a TQ of 10,000 lbs.



Because of the volume of stored regulated substances vs. the transient gas stream, only the storage area was evaluated when determining RMP eligibility or Program level.  The interconnecting piping would make the refrigeration plant part of the "process" but the requireme

nts would not change in relation to distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 psi or resulting RMP Program level.



There are four (4) pressurized bullet-type storage vessels on location:  One (1) 30,000 gallon vessel, two (2) 16,000 gallon vessels, and one (1) 14,000 gallon vessel.



The three (3) smaller tanks are produced into simultaneously until full (approximately 50,000 gallons).  The facility then produces into the 30,000 gallon tank while the others are being shipped by truck. Procedurally, the facility is limited to 50,000 gallons on-site storage and this amount was used when evaluating the Worst Case Scenario.



 

Worst Case and Alternate Release Scenarios



We used RMP*Comp and calculated a mixture of flammable substance stream as:

  Ethane as 2% of 50,000 gallons multiplied by 3.11 lbs per/gallon = 3,110 lbs

  Propane as 35.2% of 50,000 gallons multiplied by 4.224 lbs per/gallon = 74,342 lbs

  iso-Butane as 9% of 50,000 gallons multiplied by 4.685 lbs per/gallon = 15,226 lbs.

  n-Butane as 27.7% of 50,000 gallons multiplied by 4.865 lbs per/gallon = 67,380 lbs.

  iso-Pentane as 7% of 50,000 gallons multiplied by 5.194 lbs per/gallon = 18,179 lbs.

  n-Pentane as 9% of 50,000 gallons multiplied by 5.248 lbs per/gallon = 23,616 lbs.

TOTAL = 201,854 lbs



This gave us a worst case scenario (Worst Case assumes the entire contents were released and formed a vapor cloud which detonated) distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 psi of 0.5 miles.  There are approximately 7 homes with an estimated 21 residents within the 0.5 mile radius of Oneida Extraction Plant.  A ridge line on either side of the facility protects all but one of these residents from impact of a vapor cloud explosion.



The Alternate release scenario involves a Pull-Away explosion of a driver failing to remove the hose while loading.  This scenario involves a release of the entire contents of the hose of 10 gallons = ~40 lbs.  The scenario estimates a sudden release and immedia

te shutdown with the active mitigation system (Snappy Joe valves).  This gave us an alternate case scenario distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 psi of 0.03 miles.  There are three (3) residences within the 0.03 mile radius of the Oneida Extraction Plant.  Again, the ridge line on either side of the facility protects all but one of these residences from impact of a vapor cloud explosion.



Five Year Accident History



There have been no accidents with specific offsite consequences at the Oneida Extraction Plant in the past five years

Program Level



With public receptors within the distance to an endpoint from a worst case release and being subject to OSHA's PSM standard, the result is Oneida Extraction being assigned a Program 3 process.



Accidental Release Prevention Program



The Oneida Extraction Plant is subject to OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management for Highly Hazardous Chemicals(PSM).  The PSM program was implemented in January of 2002.



The Oneida Extraction Plant is also subject to EPA's 40 CFR 112.7 Spill Prevention Countermeasures and Control standard.  An SPCC is in place to establish procedures to prevent contain and control a hydrocarbon release.



The Oneida Extraction Plant complies with NFPA standard 58.



In the unlikely event of a fire at the Oneida Extraction Plant, employees may respond to an incipient stage fire and then must evacuate the facility.  An Emergency Action Plan developed to 29 CFR 1910.38(a) is in place to establish procedures for the safe evacuation of the facility and summon emergency response organizations. The Oneida Extraction Plant has coordinated response with the Oneida Volunteer Fire Department.  Members of the fire department have inspected the Liquid Storage System.
